data.title: The 50+ Best NBA Detroit Pistons Shooting Guards
data.meta_description: Over 100 sports fans have voted on the 50+ Best NBA Detroit Pistons Shooting Guards. Current Top 3: Joe Dumars, Richard Hamilton, Jerry Stackhouse
data.text:
Ranked By

1.0K votes

183 voters

4 reranks

Voting Rules

Vote up the players who had the most success for the Detroit Pistons

Big fan of Detroit basketball? Then check out this list of Detroit Pistons shooting guards. It includes almost every shooting guard from throughout Detroit Pistons history, including current shooting guards and past ones. Featuring some of the greatest NBA shooting guards of all time, the best Pistons SGs include Joe Dumars, Jerry Stackhouse, Richard Hamilton, and Davie Bing.

In the 2021-22 NBA season, the current Detroit Pistons starting SGs and backup SGs are Cade Cunningham, Frank Jackson, and Rodney McGruder.

Who are the best shooting guards in Detroit Pistons history? Vote below and help decide the greatest Detroit Pistons shooting guard of all time!

Most divisive: Avery Bradley

Over 100 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The 50+ Best NBA Detroit Pistons Shooting Guards

Birthplace : Shreveport, Louisiana

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Shooting guard

Detroit Pistons: 1985–1999

A tenacious defender and a sharpshooter from beyond the arc, Joe Dumars was an integral part of the Detroit Pistons organization for his entire 14-year NBA career. Drafted by the Pistons in 1985, he quickly established himself as a scorer and facilitator, forming one-half of the legendary "Bad Boys" backcourt alongside Isiah Thomas. Dumars helped lead the team to back-to-back NBA championships in 1989 and 1990, earning Finals MVP honors in 1989 with his clutch scoring and defensive prowess. A six-time All-Star and a five-time NBA All-Defensive First Team honoree, Dumars retired as one of the most respected and accomplished players in Pistons history.

Birthplace : Coatesville, Pennsylvania

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Chicago Bulls

Position : Point guard, Shooting guard, Small forward, Swingman

Detroit Pistons: 2002–2011

Known for his mid-range game and tireless off-ball movement, Richard Hamilton joined the Detroit Pistons in 2002 through a trade and played nine seasons with the team. As the focal point of the Pistons' offense during their dominant run in the mid-2000s, Rip led the team in scoring helping them reach six consecutive Eastern Conference Finals and capture the 2004 NBA Championship. A three-time All-Star, Hamilton's distinctive style of play, which included running defenders ragged through multiple screens, set him apart from his contemporaries and made him a fan favorite. His relentless energy and scoring ability etched his name in Pistons lore as one of the franchise's all-time great shooting guards.

Birthplace : Kinston, North Carolina, USA

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Atlanta Hawks

Position : Shooting guard, Small forward

Detroit Pistons: 1997–2002

Acquired in a trade from the Philadelphia 76ers in 1997, Jerry Stackhouse quickly emerged as a lethal scoring threat for the Detroit Pistons. Known for his explosive athleticism and jaw-dropping dunks, Stackhouse was able to score from virtually anywhere on the floor, making him a nightmare matchup for opposing defenders. He led the league in total points scored during the 2000-01 season and earned two All-Star selections while donning a Pistons uniform. Despite his individual success, Stackhouse was unable to guide the team to deep playoff runs, but his dynamic offensive prowess left a lasting impression on the franchise and its fans.

Birthplace : USA, Kentucky, Louisville

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Shooting guard

Detroit Pistons: 1993–1996

Drafted by the Detroit Pistons in 1993, Allan Houston spent the first three seasons of his NBA career in Motor City before signing with the New York Knicks. As a Piston, Houston showcased his smooth shooting stroke and developed into one of the league's most lethal marksmen from beyond the arc, earning a spot in the 1996 NBA Three-Point Shootout. Although he wouldn't reach his full potential until his tenure in New York, Houston's contributions during his time in Detroit cannot be overlooked. His shooting ability and steady scoring served as an early indication of his eventual success, and he remains one of the best pure shooters to ever suit up for the Pistons.

Birthplace : New York City, New York

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Shooting guard

Detroit Pistons: 1981–1991

The "Microwave" himself, Vinnie Johnson provided an electrifying spark off the bench for the Detroit Pistons during their "Bad Boys" era. Acquired in a trade in 1981, Johnson quickly carved out a role as the team's instant-offense sixth man, possessing an uncanny ability to heat up at a moment's notice. His clutch performances in the playoffs, including his unforgettable game-winning shot in Game 5 of the 1990 NBA Finals, were instrumental in helping the Pistons secure back-to-back championships in 1989 and 1990. Though he was never an All-Star, Johnson's scoring bursts and vital contributions during the team's most successful period earned him a well-deserved spot among the great shooting guards in franchise history.

Birthplace : Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Nationality : American

Position : Point guard, Shooting guard, Small forward

Detroit Pistons: 1996–1998

Drafted by the Detroit Pistons in 1994, Aaron McKie provided a steady blend of defense and outside shooting during his brief time with the team. Although his tenure in Detroit was short-lived, McKie's work ethic and commitment to the defensive end resonated with Piston's fans and laid the foundation for the successful career he would enjoy later on. His early contributions and potential make him a noteworthy figure in Pistons history.
